An old boss had a low tolerance for vague #promises:

“‘Sometime next week’ is not a deadline! Be specific! What day will you get back to me?”

The same is true with #CX. Be specific about what you’re measuring + doing + when. Being vague won’t build buy-in.

#CustomerExperience
What is an “amazing” experience? One that solves a #customer’s problem at a reasonable cost with no headaches. #CX

However, research shows there's a case to be made for improving the ease of regulatory compliance to avoid rule-bending, corruption, and bribery in response to perceptions of #CX red tape and sludge. Surveys can let you know what customers think.

PSA: One fast way to frowny-face ☹️ #CX feedback:

Rushing to close a #custserv ticket for the good of your own time quota, before the customer’s needs have been met.

Another way: Passing the buck without even comprehending what’s in the ticket.

Ability to intelligently flow between being a leader + being a follower. Attitude. Collaborative + critical thinking ability. Someone who honors the value of their network.

When you believe in someone, encourage them. Encouragement is free. It’s generous. And people remember when you genuinely show your support.

Who has cheered you on?

Leadership communication effectiveness is about more than what a CEO says in a town hall meeting. What is being communicated through your:

👉Organizational rules
👉Recruiting practices
👉Onboarding processes
👉Employee policies?

Avoid the pitfall of setting targets for #CX improvement that begin with verbs. 

Use terms like “number of,” “percentage of,” “average of” when you’re setting standards and goals.

The same is true with #CX metrics. Be specific about what you’re measuring + when. Vagueness won’t build buy-in.

The customer sees it as:

1⃣ Not being able to find a parking spot.

See #CX the customer's way. It may have *nothing* to do with marketing.

Fave q’s for client interviews:

What do our competitors do well that we should consider?
What are your big biz challenges in the next 1-2 years + where do you see our firm fitting in?

Use these to see yourself through the client’s eyes, get biz intel + identify BD ops. #CX #VOC

@tanujdiwan For me, I’ve been working in and with remote and virtual teams for 20 years. You have to stay organized and in-tune with the people you’re teaming with. It’s not simple. Mistakes happen. But you have to be aware of how you’re perceived as a leader.

Leading virtual teams can be a challenge.

Know what else is a challenge? 

👉Being led by a virtual manager. 

Understand how your team perceives you and your leadership style. Build skills accordingly.

#Leadership #VirtualTeams #EmployeeExperience #EmployeeEngagement

Customer experience and marketing aren’t the same thing. If you're dedicating a budget to marketing, but haven't considered the experience you're eventually leading customers to, then you're not "doing #CX." #CustServ #customerexperience

One big mistake orgs make: they believe they are “doing CX”(or employee experience) if they’re sending out an annual survey. Experience management is a business discipline that involves a range of practices, competencies, and skills you do *every day* in your biz.

“Leaders need to talk about successful renewals with just as much energy as initial sales.” @mishbatt 

How caring for customers *after* the sale boosts repeat purchases and creates loyalty.

@ICT_GURU Good point. We talk incessantly about leadership development but I don’t think we’ve ever framed followership development. It’s not as sexy as leadership so it’s ignored. Although there are some amaaaazing scholars working on it. Carsten, Kellerman, etc.

@ICT_GURU I read a stat in a scholarly pub that said leaders account for ~20% of an org’s success. The rest of the success is thanks to followers. Yet near 100% of society’s attention, even in times of failure, is on leaders. It’s a wide open area for study.

@ICT_GURU Overly romanticized views of leadership and straight up ignoring followership. Followers do most of the work. Leadership is a relationship. You see 100 books on developing leaders and how many on developing followers? 🤔

“The more you do your homework, the more you’re free to be intuitive. But you’ve got to put the work in.” ~ Edward Norton

You call it churn. The customer calls it “shopping elsewhere.”

You call it processing time. The customer sees it as wait time.

Sharing the same vocabulary with your #customer puts you on the path to a more customer-centric culture.

Red tape. 😑🤨

It obliterates the employee experience just as much as the customer experience. 

Don't make it hard for #employees to talk to you, to be rewarded, follow rules, or pursue a promotion.

Why would they *want* to improve #CX if their own experience is too hard?

We've all seen this #CX tweet 1,000 times:

A great employee experience leads to a great customer experience!

Think about what that means. Every org has systemic problems. Finding a way forward requires acknowledging + tackling the hard stuff. Not defaulting to easy fixes. #CX

Some of the hardest work you will do in #CX is with internal coalition-building. Communicate, listen to colleagues, #collaborate, and persevere. The work is worth doing.

You call it churn. The customer calls it “shopping elsewhere.”

You call it processing time. The customer sees it as wait time.

Sharing the same vocabulary with your #customer puts you on the path to a more customer-centric culture.

Try it and see. #cx #customerexperience

Leaders encouraged and empowered employees.

Employees supported one another even when they didn’t see each other very often, if ever.

We found ways to say yes to each other rather than automatically diverting to “no.” We were all on the same team. The client’s team.

One of the things EY did right: Culture.

Knowing how to lead + play on a virtual or #hybrid team was expected of employees.

Tech + tech support was 💯 24/7. There was never a problem that couldn’t be solved.

Virtual and hybrid can rock. But it takes #culture to make it fly.

20 years ago I started a 9-year run at @EY_US.

From day one our teams were spread across geography. We were “virtual” + “hybrid.”

Every year I worked there EY made the “Best Place to Work” lists. 🏅 

Virtual and hybrid can be done well. It *has* been done well.

@thatcxguytweets So then can we really ever have a "single" view? #CXChat  🤔
@SueDuris I find that people who have never actually practiced the discipline of #CX simply do not understand what governance looks like in practice. Just my anecdotal observation. #CXChat

🤔We're falling too deeply in love with ourselves if we think a #CX leader's single view is the only single view that matters in an org. What a CFO wants in their "single view" of customers will be different from what a CMO wants in their single view. #CXChat

I would also argue there's no one single view, even if you can unite the data silos. A risk manager's preferred "single view" of a customer is going to be quite different from a marketing leader's "single view" of a customer. #CXChat

One reason I'm getting hung up on answering is governance. Should data be in one place? Yes. Should everyone in a company have access to all customer data all the time? Not necessarily. Access rights would be highly contextual, based on the org. #CXChat

I'm hung up on answering for the nuanced reasons mentioned by @thatcxguytweets. Is it important to have your customer data in one place? Yes. Is it important for everyone to have the exact same view of the customer? Not necessarily. #CXChat
@thatcxguytweets Definitely appreciate the call out to "nuanced implementation." #CXChat

A7 | #CXChat

You bring up a good point that your overarching #governance framework needs a regular check-up. The pieces and parts, of course, need regular care and feeding. But so does the big framework. #CX
@JoshVoC @thatcxguytweets For a minute I thought you were talking about a group of kids bickering over who got the biggest piece of pizza. J/K LOL #CXChat

A6 | #CXChat

Start with the easily digestible to-dos. If it's setting up the governance features in your VOC platform, start there. If it's creating some structure around a #CX advocates committee, go for it. Then grow it.
@thatcxguytweets It takes a very strong leader to help people understand that governance is not a policing mechanism. It is a triage mechanism. #CXChat

@carriemaslen @EJEngwall These points on purpose and inclusion should be outlined in a governance group charter. A document that lives with other operational policies within your organization. #CXChat

A4 | #CXChat

I wouldn't say lack of governance is *the* reason for low #CX program maturity. There are also root causes for not having governance mechanisms in place. Lack of skill and knowledge, apathy, resources, etc. So, I would argue it's not just one thing.

A3 | #CXChat

Governance has so many dimensions in #CX, though. It can also be about setting up the governance features in your VOC platform. Who gets to see #data and who doesn't. Again, structure.

A3 | #CXChat

Governance not happening is a casualty of the assumption that #CX is everyone's responsibility. You really need to have someone in charge who understands the granularity of governance and can drive the bus, so to speak.

A3 | #CXChat

Governance is the secret sauce for assuring the longevity of your #CX work.

A1 | #CXChat

Governance is about structure. Specifics, actions, and doing something. Survey policies, standards, reviews of the organization's performance to its #CX targets, operational guidelines for #CX teams...

A1 | #CXChat

From an operational perspective, you need to have standards and review with a team your organization's performance to those standards regularly... Operational data, experience data, etc. #CX

A1 | #CXChat

I think it's important to be specific when we say #CX reviews. Are we reviewing #CX data, programs, policies? Everything? Something else?

Virtual tech event planners:

You must cut the jargon, technical terms, + buzz words from your talks + session descriptions. 

Remember who you're talking to. It's not just tech-savvy buyers. It's others who can influence a buy. 

Talk about the biz problems your tech solves.

📊 Spreadsheets and checklists are great for helping you understand customer transactions. But you need more if you want to understand your customer’s experiences. Ask questions and get feedback that helps you understand the human beings behind the numbers. #cx

There are more ways to lose a customer's trust now than there ever have been. 

Steal their data.
Add so much red tape to their lives they cry.
Say one thing and do another.
Don't take feedback seriously.
Deliver an order that looks like it's been run over.

#CustServ

🧐 You may need to do more than just shorten a #survey to get better response rates from #customers.

Do the answer options make sense in the context of the question?

Confusing surveys are a reason for customers to abandon.

Don’t skimp on survey design. Hire a pro to help.👇 https://t.co/1n3GpAfQav

⚡️One sure way to low #survey response rates: bad writing + design.

If the customer didn’t track her order, then she shouldn’t be “required” to rate the ease of tracking. 

Let customers answer the way they want. Otherwise, there’s no point in taking the survey. 🧐⚡️#CX https://t.co/RdcMoL9D7U

Been thinking about this lately while studying the #CX aspects of administrative red tape. Often, orgs are more worried about compliance/following rules. It's not an option to de-prioritize those things. Doesn't make it right. But important to u/s the whole biz reality. #CXChat

You would uncover problems like rigid hierarchy, rules that make it hard to be rewarded for good performance, rules that discourage employees from seeking promotions... all of these things kill your chances for happy employees. #CXChat

If you take a look at the empirical literature on employee change support intentions and administrative red tape, it is easy to see why you need to map employee journeys. It can be argued that more red tape=less employee support for organizational change. #CXChat #CX

Popping by #CXChat. Can't stay! But for this question, my answer is no. Like many other things, managers think they just know what employees want. Or, they are more concerned with making sure employees follow rules on the job, so there's no time or resources left for VOE. #CX

"There is an illusion in the world of #business that makes companies believe they're innovating in delivering #CX just because they're investing in new digital platforms... Tech is not CX... Use tech as an enabler." Well said, @luismelo78. #CXQOTD

Decide. Define a target. Measure it. Triage it. Share the follow-up to-dos with teammates.

Fave q's for client interviews:

What do our competitors do well that we should consider?
What are your big biz challenges in the next 1-2 years + where do you see our firm fitting in?

Use these to see yourself through the client's eyes, get biz intel + identify BD ops. #CX #VOC

Red tape. 😑🤨

It obliterates the employee experience just as much as the customer experience. 

Don't make it hard for #employees to talk to you, to be rewarded, follow rules, or pursue a promotion.

Why would they *want* to improve #CX if their own experience is too hard?

📢”You are always communicating.” 

That’s great advice from a former mentor.

That means, in #business, if you’re not responding to #customers, that’s *not* not communicating. 

Radio silence sends a message, too. #CX

How to Avoid Operational Meltdowns with Virtual Teams.

Straight up, my friends: 

You must talk about business performance. You must be direct, or you risk misalignment and meltdowns.

#CX #Leadership #CustomerExperience #virtualteam  https://t.co/fPVEehRl6V

"We promise to provide a better customer experience."
